category_summary:
**Anthropic** dominated the day with a landmark AI safety announcement: **Claude Opus 4.6** is approaching ASL-4 capability thresholds, and the company is preemptively applying its highest safety standards, publishing its first [sabotage risk report](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-92a718e1a2d9) for frontier autonomous AI R&D. Separately, **Anthropic** [committed to covering](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-8cd633d16d8e) 100% of electricity price increases from its data centers, a major infrastructure policy move.

- **Andrej Karpathy** drove massive engagement with two posts: a [detailed walkthrough](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-fb1b858f8eeb) of using **DeepWiki** MCP to extract library functionality via agents (5K likes), and the [release of a 243-line](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-3685549e1b3b) dependency-free Python GPT implementation (6.5K likes), reinforcing themes of software malleability and minimalism in the AI era
- **Sam Altman** [announced a GPT-5.2 update](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-51e4e7e6e5f0) in **ChatGPT** and expressed confidence that **Codex** is winning the AI coding race faster than expected (874K views)
- **Jason Warner** (Poolside CEO) [published a strategic thesis](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-5ce505a8fecb) arguing intelligence is the new critical infrastructure, comparing AI providers to cloud and energy utilities
- **Google DeepMind** [shared research](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-0e4dbd1a5ef0) showing **Gemini Deep Think** uses agentic workflows to help solve research-level problems in math, physics, and computer science
- **Boris Cherny** (Anthropic) [detailed **Claude Code's**](/?date=2026-02-12&category=social#item-f7f1809b05ef) extensive customization system‚Äîhooks, plugins, LSPs, MCPs‚Äîsignaling a strategy to win developers through configurability
category_summary_html:
Anthropic dominated the day with a landmark AI safety announcement: Claude Opus 4.6 is approaching ASL-4 capability thresholds, and the company is preemptively applying its highest safety standards, publishing its first sabotage risk report for frontier autonomous AI R&D. Separately, Anthropic committed to covering 100% of electricity price increases from its data centers, a major infrastructure policy move.

  • Andrej Karpathy drove massive engagement with two posts: a detailed walkthrough of using DeepWiki MCP to extract library functionality via agents (5K likes), and the release of a 243-line dependency-free Python GPT implementation (6.5K likes), reinforcing themes of software malleability and minimalism in the AI era
  • Sam Altman announced a GPT-5.2 update in ChatGPT and expressed confidence that Codex is winning the AI coding race faster than expected (874K views)
  • Jason Warner (Poolside CEO) published a strategic thesis arguing intelligence is the new critical infrastructure, comparing AI providers to cloud and energy utilities
  • Google DeepMind shared research showing Gemini Deep Think uses agentic workflows to help solve research-level problems in math, physics, and computer science

themes.name: Software Development Paradigm Shift
themes.description: Karpathy's influential posts on dependency-free 'bacterial code,' using AI agents with DeepWiki to extract and simplify library functionality, and the idea that 'libraries are over, LLMs are the new compiler.' Also includes the 243-line GPT project as the ultimate minimalist implementation.

themes.name: Anthropic Claude Opus 4.6 Safety & ASL-4
themes.description: Anthropic releases sabotage risk report for Opus 4.6, preemptively meeting ASL-4 safety bar for autonomous AI R&D. Signals models are approaching dangerous capability thresholds.

themes.name: AI Product Momentum & Competition
themes.description: Sam Altman's GPT-5.2 update and Codex confidence, Anthropic's energy commitment, Claude Cowork demonstrations, pace of impactful AI releases accelerating across companies.

themes.name: GPT-5.3 Codex vs Claude Competition
themes.description: Multiple users report GPT-5.3 Codex as fast, efficient, and comparable to Claude for coding, with at least one prominent user cancelling their Claude Max subscription. Claude's latest update criticized as slow and expensive.

themes.name: Claude Code Customization & Features
themes.description: Comprehensive thread from Anthropic's Boris Cherny detailing Claude Code's extensive customization: plugins, LSPs, MCPs, custom agents, hooks, sandboxing, permissions, effort levels, status lines, output styles, and keybindings. Major product awareness push showing Claude Code's strategy as a highly configurable terminal-native AI coding tool.

themes.name: AI Business Strategy & Infrastructure
themes.description: Jason Warner's extensive thesis that intelligence is the new critical infrastructure, arguing large companies must build their own models or face obsolescence. Compares AI model providers to cloud hyperscalers.

themes.name: Agentic AI & Enterprise Adoption
themes.description: Allie K Miller's posts about C-suite excitement for agentic platforms (Claude Code, Codex, OpenClaw) and Claude Cowork Legal plugin, combined with van Loon's ServiceNow thread on enterprise scaling, indicate a pivotal moment in enterprise AI adoption.

themes.name: AI Infrastructure & Energy
themes.description: Anthropic's major commitment to cover electricity costs from data centers, pay for grid upgrades. Emollick noting compute scarcity.

themes.name: AI Impact Communication & Public Understanding
themes.description: Matt Shumer's viral article (1.3M views) about explaining AI to non-technical people, emphasizing urgency for those outside tech to understand imminent AI impact. Written for his parents, it resonated massively.

themes.name: AI Hype vs. Reality Gap
themes.description: Multiple posts highlight the disconnect between AI hype narratives and actual usability, with Tunguz's Gemini frustration, Claude Code critique, and Silicon Valley bubble critique forming a coherent counter-narrative to AI optimism.

items.title:
On DeepWiki and increasing malleability of software.

This starts as partially a post on appreciatio...
items.content:
On DeepWiki and increasing malleability of software.

This starts as partially a post on appreciation to DeepWiki, which I routinely find very useful and I think more people would find useful to know about. I went through a few iterations of use:

Their first feature was that it auto-builds wiki pages for github repos (e.g. nanochat here) with quick Q&A:
https://t.co/DQHXagUwK0
Just swap "github" to "deepwiki" in the URL for any repo and you can instantly Q&A against it. For example, yesterday I was curious about "how does torchao implement fp8 training?". I find that in *many* cases, library docs can be spotty and outdated and bad, but directly asking questions to the code via DeepWiki works very well. The code is the source of truth and LLMs are increasingly able to understand it.

But then I realized that in many cases it's even a lot more powerful not being the direct (human) consumer of this information/functionality, but giving your agent access to DeepWiki via MCP. So e.g. yesterday I faced some annoyances with using torchao library for fp8 training and I had the suspicion that the whole thing really shouldn't be that complicated (wait shouldn't this be a Function like Linear except with a few extra casts and 3 calls to torch._scaled_mm?) so I tried:

"Use DeepWiki MCP and Github CLI to look at how torchao implements fp8 training. Is it possible to 'rip out' the functionality? Implement nanochat/fp8.py that has identical API but is fully self-contained"

Claude went off for 5 minutes and came back with 150 lines of clean code that worked out of the box, with tests proving equivalent results, which allowed me to delete torchao as repo dependency, and for some reason I still don't fully understand (I think it has to do with internals of torch compile) - this simple version runs 3% faster. The agent also found a lot of tiny implementation details that actually do matter, that I may have naively missed otherwise and that would have been very hard for maintainers to keep docs about. Tricks around numerics, dtypes, autocast, meta device, torch compile interactions so I learned a lot from the process too. So this is now the default fp8 training implementation for nanochat
https://t.co/3i5cv6grWm

Anyway TLDR I find this combo of DeepWiki MCP + GitHub CLI is quite powerful to "rip out" any specific functionality from any github repo and target it for the very specific use case that you have in mind, and it actually kind of works now in some cases. Maybe you don't download, configure and take dependency on a giant monolithic library, maybe you point your agent at it and rip out the exact part you need. Maybe this informs how we write software more generally to actively encourage this workflow - e.g. building more "bacterial code", code that is less tangled, more self-contained, more dependency-free, more stateless, much easier to rip out from the repo (https://t.co/iKJUoHiIpl) 
There's obvious downsides and risks to this, but it is fundamentally a new option that was not possible or economical before (it would have cost too much time) but now with agents, it is. Software might become a lot more fluid and malleable. "Libraries are over, LLMs are the new compiler" :). And does your project really need its 100MB of dependencies?

items.title: When we released Claude Opus 4.5, we knew future models would be close to our AI Safety Level 4 thre...
items.content:
When we released Claude Opus 4.5, we knew future models would be close to our AI Safety Level 4 threshold for autonomous AI R&D. We therefore committed to writing sabotage risk reports for future frontier models.

Today we‚Äôre delivering on that commitment for Claude Opus 4.6.
items.author: @AnthropicAI
items.summary: Following yesterday's [Research](/?date=2026-02-11&category=research#item-8bcb574e900f) coverage of the Opus 4.6 system card, Anthropic announces they're delivering on their commitment to write sabotage risk reports for frontier models, starting with Claude Opus 4.6. They noted when releasing Opus 4.5 that future models would be close to ASL-4 threshold for autonomous AI R&D.
items.reasoning: The lead tweet of Anthropic's major announcement about Claude Opus 4.6 approaching ASL-4 threshold for autonomous AI R&D. Massive engagement (2.5M views, 5.9K likes). This is a landmark AI safety disclosure and confirms Opus 4.6's capabilities are nearing autonomous AI R&D levels.

items.title:
:taps the sign:

https://t.co/JgKbHvYLRW

This isn't about Cursor, so forget the name used. This is ...
items.content:
:taps the sign:

https://t.co/JgKbHvYLRW

This isn't about Cursor, so forget the name used. This is about what is happening in the world. Cursor, as I understand it, is finetuning chinese models so at least they realize what I'm about to say.

Let's walk through this so we fully understand it. 

In the '90s a bunch of tech companies built out the internet. Those tech companies became critical infrastructure and were massively rewarded for it and became new tech giants. That infrastructure allowed a whole new type of company to exist, companies like Amazon and Google and eventually Facebook. And for companies like Microsoft to make a transition if they could see the future (folks like IBM and Oracle didn't see the future).

In the '00s, those same companies built out new critical infrastructure called hyperscaler clouds which enabled a whole new generation of company to exist. Those hyperscalers became the most valuable companies in the world bc they controlled the most valuable commoditized asset on the planet at the time. And the new companies they enabled, the likes of AirBnB, Uber, GitHub, Shopify etc, became great companies in their own right...but nothing like the scale of AWS, Azure, GCP etc. 

Now it's happening again. Intelligence is becoming the new critical infrastructure upon which every company on the planet will build. It is enabling new types of companies to exist that couldn't before. And like the previous transitions, companies that see this transition can create and capture value in bold new ways. 

Right now it's down to a handful of companies. Google is the only full stack player: They have dirt, datacenters campuses, TPUs, GCP, and Gemini. By default, they lap the Amazon and Microsoft (don't get me started on Microsoft's continued fumbles here). They are 100% fully vertically integrated. When they got good at building Gemini, it all fell together for them for the next two decades.

OpenAI, Anthropic (best independent lab on the planet and only investable frontier lab IMO), and perhaps xAI round out the frontier capable players. Poolside, Chinese labs (with Poolside, the most efficient labs in the world...see notes at bottom), and (perhaps) SSI will eventually become frontier capable. Those round out the list. 

Three things matter for the next decade: 

1. Energy Infrastructure
2. Compute Infrastructure
3. Intelligence Infrastructure

Most things after those are rounding errors. 

1+2 = powered datacenter campuses
3 = frontier model providers or domain specific model providers
1+2+3 = full vertical integration 

At Poolside we have a saying which is "Everything collapses into the model" which means that eventually all things we think of as valuable become part of the models (and agents*) that get produced. 

*Note: first party agents from model providers will *always* be better than third party agents that come from non-model providers. This is simply a reality that modern agents and models are trained together. This really really means a large company producing an agent without backing of it's own model is especially vulnerable.

Another way to think of it is that the surface area available to applications is exactly equal to the current  capability gaps of this generation models. Each time models become more capable, they eat up more surface area available to third party applications *that are simply arbitraging the current model generation capability gap*. 

This doesn't mean third party apps aren't valuable, but it does mean if the only value third party apps have is the current capability gaps of models, those third party apps have diminishing value. 

This is not debatable in 2026. It arguably wasn't debatable when I wrote the post a full two years ago either, except people are really bad at living in an exponential. You know who isn't bad at living in an exponential? Jensen. Nvidia gets exactly what is happening while wall street futzes around with "capex buildout costs", Jensen knows exactly where every gigawatt in the world is going because he knows the future. Do you think you are smarter than Jensen? I know I'm not. 

How should non-model companies (and companies who are incapable of building models) behave in this moment? 

It's simple but not easy:

Get good at building smaller but still capable models that push *your value prop*. Do not cede your ground to third party model providers hoping you can hold on and survive, you won't be able to with the fullness of time. The tech is just too powerful. 

If you are a company with a mid double digit billions market cap and above and you are not making models, you are default long-tail dying right now. It is your job to figure out how you don't die. 

"But Jason, what about data as a moat?"

Data is valuable but if your *only* valuable asset is data, you are fighting a multi-pronged war. And if this is true it is even more paramount that you get good at training your own models. My god, this makes the whole thing more existential for you!

"But Jason, it costs so much to build models! How can one compete with how much money the model providers raised?"

Here's real dirty little secret of the AI industry. That's not real. https://t.co/i7LRIAWKSR

OpenAI 2024 compute spend above ^^. It cost them roughly $500m to build frontier model in 2024. But they spend $4.5b on RnD, which means, clusters for their researchers. The dirty little secret of the AI industry is there is no such thing as a gigawatt training cluster, there is no such thing as networking a million GPUs to train a model. The cost to train frontier AI is people with knowledge, a system capable of experimenting to find and iterate on model recipes, and $500m to train the final recipe. The first two are the hard part. The third one is just cost of doing business. 

And we wrote extensively about Poolside's way of building models which allows Poolside to do things that frontier labs do but at a fraction of the cost and fraction of the time. We call it the Model Factory and it's part of our secret weapons (along with our proprietary RL research): https://t.co/RL7PG2fK3f

Every single company worth double digit billions not getting good at training their own model is the modern equivalent of saying "I can't possibly run a database as good as Oracle therefore I shouldn't try and just pay Oracle to do it" or "It costs too much for me to have engineers build and maintain our software, I'll just pay Accenture and Microsoft to do it". 

How many of us would build our forever homes (our companies) on two year leased back land (api call to model provider where we pass all our data to them)? I prefer to own the ground my home is built on. 

Get good at building your company specific models or look back in 10 years and realize you IBMed yourself.
items.author: @jasoncwarner
items.summary: Jason Warner (Poolside CEO) writes an extensive essay arguing that intelligence is the new critical infrastructure, comparing AI model providers to cloud hyperscalers. Key arguments: (1) Google is the only full-stack AI player, (2) large companies MUST train their own models or die, (3) frontier model training costs ~$500M not billions, (4) first-party agents will always beat third-party ones, (5) app companies are just arbitraging current model capability gaps. Promotes Poolside's 'Model Factory' approach.
items.reasoning: Highest importance in batch. Comprehensive strategic thesis from Poolside CEO with 64K views and 285 likes. Controversial and thought-provoking claims about AI industry structure, model economics, and company survival. Contains specific data points (OpenAI's $500M training cost vs $4.5B R&D). Important framing that will generate debate. Some self-promotion but the analysis transcends that.

This doesn't mean third party apps aren't valuable, but it does mean if the only value third party apps have is the current capability gaps of models, those third party apps have diminishing value.

This is not debatable in 2026. It arguably wasn't debatable when I wrote the post a full two years ago either, except people are really bad at living in an exponential. You know who isn't bad at living in an exponential? Jensen. Nvidia gets exactly what is happening while wall street futzes around with "capex buildout costs", Jensen knows exactly where every gigawatt in the world is going because he knows the future. Do you think you are smarter than Jensen? I know I'm not.

How should non-model companies (and companies who are incapable of building models) behave in this moment?

It's simple but not easy:

Get good at building smaller but still capable models that push *your value prop*. Do not cede your ground to third party model providers hoping you can hold on and survive, you won't be able to with the fullness of time. The tech is just too powerful.

If you are a company with a mid double digit billions market cap and above and you are not making models, you are default long-tail dying right now. It is your job to figure out how you don't die.

"But Jason, what about data as a moat?"

Data is valuable but if your *only* valuable asset is data, you are fighting a multi-pronged war. And if this is true it is even more paramount that you get good at training your own models. My god, this makes the whole thing more existential for you!

"But Jason, it costs so much to build models! How can one compete with how much money the model providers raised?"

Here's real dirty little secret of the AI industry. That's not real. https://t.co/i7LRIAWKSR

OpenAI 2024 compute spend above ^^. It cost them roughly $500m to build frontier model in 2024. But they spend $4.5b on RnD, which means, clusters for their researchers. The dirty little secret of the AI industry is there is no such thing as a gigawatt training cluster, there is no such thing as networking a million GPUs to train a model. The cost to train frontier AI is people with knowledge, a system capable of experimenting to find and iterate on model recipes, and $500m to train the final recipe. The first two are the hard part. The third one is just cost of doing business.

And we wrote extensively about Poolside's way of building models which allows Poolside to do things that frontier labs do but at a fraction of the cost and fraction of the time. We call it the Model Factory and it's part of our secret weapons (along with our proprietary RL research): https://t.co/RL7PG2fK3f

Every single company worth double digit billions not getting good at training their own model is the modern equivalent of saying "I can't possibly run a database as good as Oracle therefore I shouldn't try and just pay Oracle to do it" or "It costs too much for me to have engineers build and maintain our software, I'll just pay Accenture and Microsoft to do it".

How many of us would build our forever homes (our companies) on two year leased back land (api call to model provider where we pass all our data to them)? I prefer to own the ground my home is built on.

Get good at building your company specific models or look back in 10 years and realize you IBMed yourself.

items.title: Reflecting on what engineers love about Claude Code, one thing that jumps out is its customizability...
items.content:
Reflecting on what engineers love about Claude Code, one thing that jumps out is its customizability: hooks, plugins, LSPs, MCPs, skills, effort, custom agents, status lines, output styles, etc.

Every engineer uses their tools differently. We built Claude Code from the ground up to not just have great defaults, but to also be incredibly customizable. This is a reason why developers fall in love with the product, and why Claude Code's growth continues to accelerate.  

I wanted to share a few ways we're seeing people and teams customize their Claudes.

items.title:

This is the /legal:triage-nda call that reviews ND...
items.content:
My first rodeo with Claude Cowork Legal plugin. 

This is the /legal:triage-nda call that reviews NDAs against a set of criteria (you can specify your own criteria or go with Claude's market-standard defaults). This is a real review of an NDA sent to me by a client.

I can understand why legal stocks were rocked. 

Lawyers, do we like this? Are you happy tiny tasks like NDA reviews won't hit your desk as often? Are we transitioning away from billable hours? DM me.

items.title: The way it works is that the full LLM architecture and loss function is stripped entirely to the mos...
items.content: The way it works is that the full LLM architecture and loss function is stripped entirely to the most atomic individual mathematical operations that make it up (+, *, **, log, exp), and then a tiny scalar-valued autograd engine (micrograd) calculates gradients. Adam for optim.

items.summary: Karpathy explains the technical details of his minimal GPT implementation - how the full LLM architecture is decomposed into atomic math operations with a scalar autograd engine (micrograd) for gradient computation.

So the two are equivalent now in terms of debugging capability, but Anthropic did something to Claude in the latest update, so it is now terribly slow, and if you pay for tokens, then terribly expensive.

Codex, in my experience, is super fast and efficient.

items.title:
Coding agents are not great for open-source software, and it needs to adapt

This is a really nice a...
items.content:
Coding agents are not great for open-source software, and it needs to adapt

This is a really nice article from @LoganMarkewich that draws from our experience maintaining our own OSS library in the past 3 years.

1. Open-source used to be nice for human knowledge sharing. Now you really need to optimize it so that coding agents can pick it up.

2. Light abstractions (wrappers around LLMs, vector databases, etc.) are dead 

3. There is a massive slopocalypse of ai-generated PRs, which breaks the fun community feeling of OSS. If you want to lean in and accept this, you need to document patterns clearly so coding agents can pick it up 

https://t.co/uSNrxjVlOO
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) argues coding agents are poor for open-source software. OSS needs to adapt: optimize docs for agents, light abstractions are dead, and AI-generated PRs are creating a 'slopocalypse' that degrades community.
items.reasoning: Highly relevant and original insight from the LlamaIndex founder about a real structural problem: how coding agents are reshaping open-source culture. Practical implications for OSS maintainers. Moderate engagement.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) argues coding agents are poor for open-source software. OSS needs to adapt: optimize docs for agents, light abstractions are dead, and AI-generated PRs are creating a 'slopocalypse' that degrades community.

This is a really nice article from @LoganMarkewich that draws from our experience maintaining our own OSS library in the past 3 years.

2. Light abstractions (wrappers around LLMs, vector databases, etc.) are dead

3. There is a massive slopocalypse of ai-generated PRs, which breaks the fun community feeling of OSS. If you want to lean in and accept this, you need to document patterns clearly so coding agents can pick it up

items.title:
What took me a week to build out a year ago just took me about 15 seconds. 

Since late 2022, I've b...
items.content:
What took me a week to build out a year ago just took me about 15 seconds. 

Since late 2022, I've been assigning personas to LLMs to have them poke the hell out of my work. 

"Review this product launch from Steve Jobs' POV"

"Act as drunk Shakespeare and make this funnier"

"Pretend you are Lara Croft and give me advice for this camping trip"

Then GPTs came out, and I built GPTs for each persona, plus some GPTs with multiple personas. I could open the GPT and ask my "board of advisors" what they thought of certain tasks or strategies or ideas. 

Then I built my own boardroom app that allowed for multiple LLMs to argue in the same war room. I had multiple Gemini, Claude, and OpenAI models, each with different personas, going back and forth on ideas until a moderator determined the argument was 95% settled and shared back a decision document (with decisions, rankings, tradeoffs, etc). 

And today, I created a skill in Claude Code that calls an Agent Team of my board of advisors that does just that, and it took a short dictation and 15 seconds of input. 

I invoke it with /boardroom - that kicks off 6 agents, each with my 414-line business context document and personality profile, they all argue with each other, and creates a folder with the decision as the title, and within that creates a md file with core decision, html file with interactive assumptions and changes, and pdf file to send to team members or review later if i want. 

I'm in awe. 

I love being in awe.
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie K Miller describes her evolution from manually assigning LLM personas (2022) to building custom GPTs to creating a multi-LLM boardroom app, and now using Claude Code skills to create a '/boardroom' command that deploys 6 AI agents with business context to debate and produce decision documents in 15 seconds.
items.reasoning: Excellent practical demonstration of AI agent orchestration workflow evolution. Allie Miller is a prominent AI voice. Shows concrete, reproducible workflow with Claude Code skills. Good engagement (270 likes, 17K views). Demonstrates how agentic tools are collapsing complex multi-model workflows into simple commands.
items.summary_html: Allie K Miller describes her evolution from manually assigning LLM personas (2022) to building custom GPTs to creating a multi-LLM boardroom app, and now using Claude Code skills to create a '/boardroom' command that deploys 6 AI agents with business context to debate and produce decision documents in 15 seconds.
items.content_html:
What took me a week to build out a year ago just took me about 15 seconds.

Since late 2022, I've been assigning personas to LLMs to have them poke the hell out of my work.

"Review this product launch from Steve Jobs' POV"

"Act as drunk Shakespeare and make this funnier"

"Pretend you are Lara Croft and give me advice for this camping trip"

Then GPTs came out, and I built GPTs for each persona, plus some GPTs with multiple personas. I could open the GPT and ask my "board of advisors" what they thought of certain tasks or strategies or ideas.

Then I built my own boardroom app that allowed for multiple LLMs to argue in the same war room. I had multiple Gemini, Claude, and OpenAI models, each with different personas, going back and forth on ideas until a moderator determined the argument was 95% settled and shared back a decision document (with decisions, rankings, tradeoffs, etc).

And today, I created a skill in Claude Code that calls an Agent Team of my board of advisors that does just that, and it took a short dictation and 15 seconds of input.

I invoke it with /boardroom - that kicks off 6 agents, each with my 414-line business context document and personality profile, they all argue with each other, and creates a folder with the decision as the title, and within that creates a md file with core decision, html file with interactive assumptions and changes, and pdf file to send to team members or review later if i want.

I'm in awe.

I love being in awe.

items.content:
üá≥üá±üóΩ This is @BytedanceTalk's Seedance 2.0 with my New Amsterdam (current day New York City) Simulator prompt

Unlike previous models like Seedance 1.5 (which would add windmills that didn't look Dutch), it really accurately portrays the city as it was in 1670

It's very impressive and because it takes reference image/video/audio, you can put yourself in it like I did here

Only thing bad I see is some distortion in is some of the text which other video models seem to do better now, but yes it's very impressive

This is purposely made to look a bit like a game, so it can do more photorealism than this actually

items.title: At a high level, Kaggle and machine learning benchmarks look very similar: Find methods that achieve...
items.content:
At a high level, Kaggle and machine learning benchmarks look very similar: Find methods that achieve high test performance on unseen data. 
However, hillclimbing on ML benchmarks has been a major driver of fundamental breakthroughs in ML, while Kaggle has not.
Could it be possible that the same applies to automated AI research? If so, we should probably stop evaluating  (mostly) on Kaggle style tasks but have our agents target core ML benchmarks instead. 
Good idea? We thought so, too! This took some time to get out but we are happy to finally introduce AIRS-Bench, a major step in this direction!
items.author: @j_foerst
items.summary: Introducing AIRS-Bench, a benchmark for automated AI research agents that targets core ML benchmarks rather than Kaggle-style tasks, arguing that hillclimbing on ML benchmarks drives fundamental breakthroughs while Kaggle has not.
items.reasoning: Novel benchmark proposal with interesting thesis about ML benchmarks vs Kaggle for AI research agents. Moderate engagement, niche but relevant to AI research evaluation.
items.summary_html: Introducing AIRS-Bench, a benchmark for automated AI research agents that targets core ML benchmarks rather than Kaggle-style tasks, arguing that hillclimbing on ML benchmarks drives fundamental breakthroughs while Kaggle has not.
items.content_html:
At a high level, Kaggle and machine learning benchmarks look very similar: Find methods that achieve high test performance on unseen data.

However, hillclimbing on ML benchmarks has been a major driver of fundamental breakthroughs in ML, while Kaggle has not.

Could it be possible that the same applies to automated AI research? If so, we should probably stop evaluating (mostly) on Kaggle style tasks but have our agents target core ML benchmarks instead.

Good idea? We thought so, too! This took some time to get out but we are happy to finally introduce AIRS-Bench, a major step in this direction!

items.title:

To create custom agents, drop .md files in .claude/agents. Each agent can h...
items.content:
4/ Create custom agents

To create custom agents, drop .md files in .claude/agents. Each agent can have a custom name, color, tool set, pre-allowed and pre-disallowed tools, permission mode, and model.

There's also a little-known feature in Claude Code that lets you set the default agent used for the main conversation. Just set the "agent" field in your settings.json or use the --agent flag.

Run /agents to get started, or learn more: https://t.co/s2p4ZXREOi

There's also a little-known feature in Claude Code that lets you set the default agent used for the main conversation. Just set the "agent" field in your settings.json or use the --agent flag.

Run /agents to get started, or learn more: https://t.co/s2p4ZXREOi

items.title: ‚ú® Finally got access to Seedance 2.0 and nobody asked me to tweet this so now it's just me and my cu...
items.content:
‚ú® Finally got access to Seedance 2.0 and nobody asked me to tweet this so now it's just me and my curiosity

What's interesting is how Seedance 2.0 lets you attach any type of media to your prompt

Like a reference photo of each actor, a pic of their clothes, an audio track of music or voice, even an entire video that it should add, and it combines that all with your prompt into a video with great audio built in

And in the prompt you can tell it what to do just like you do with images on Nano Banana Pro "extend this video backward, replace this with that" etc. 

It's like a video generation and edit model in one with image, audio and video support

Absolutely amazing and a real breakthrough
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio gives an enthusiastic review of Seedance 2.0, highlighting its multimodal video generation capabilities - attach reference photos, audio, video to prompts, combining them into generated video with built-in audio. Describes it as a combined video generation and editing model.
items.reasoning: High engagement (160K views, 1.4K likes) from prominent indie maker. Substantive first-look review of a new AI video generation tool with multimodal input capabilities. Relevant to AI-generated media trends.
items.summary_html: Levelsio gives an enthusiastic review of Seedance 2.0, highlighting its multimodal video generation capabilities - attach reference photos, audio, video to prompts, combining them into generated video with built-in audio. Describes it as a combined video generation and editing model.
items.content_html:
‚ú® Finally got access to Seedance 2.0 and nobody asked me to tweet this so now it's just me and my curiosity

What's interesting is how Seedance 2.0 lets you attach any type of media to your prompt

Like a reference photo of each actor, a pic of their clothes, an audio track of music or voice, even an entire video that it should add, and it combines that all with your prompt into a video with great audio built in

And in the prompt you can tell it what to do just like you do with images on Nano Banana Pro "extend this video backward, replace this with that" etc.

It's like a video generation and edit model in one with image, audio and video support

Absolutely amazing and a real breakthrough

items.content: Everyone is sharing this, and for the most part it‚Äôs a pretty good essay. I get everything he‚Äôs saying. Yet, and it‚Äôs a very big yet, he is still operating and thinking from an incredibly niche bubble. People who build apps bubble. That bubble, despite what its members may think, is insanely confined. For a generation the whole Silicon Valley was working under the delusion that ‚Äúsoftware was eating the world‚Äù. Which, to put it mildly, was exceedingly overexaggerated.

items.content: @marksaroufim Good to hear! Almost every code base is suddenly half "useful library code" (legacy) and half "docs++". i.e. with LLMs in hand, the torchao repo is *significantly* better docs on how to do fp8 training in PyTorch than official fp8 training docs. This is new & interesting.

items.title:
üöÄ vLLM just hit 70K GitHub stars! üéâ

The engine has kept evolving fast since the last milestone. We'...
items.content:
üöÄ vLLM just hit 70K GitHub stars! üéâ

The engine has kept evolving fast since the last milestone. We've been pushing hard on large-scale serving ‚Äî production-grade multi-node support on NVIDIA Blackwell with WideEP and expert parallelism, making it practical to serve the biggest models at scale. More models, more hardware, async scheduling for higher throughput, real-time streaming for speech and audio, and a growing multimodal story across text, vision, video, and voice.

Huge thanks to our sponsors, our 2,100+ contributors, friends at @PyTorch, @huggingface Transformers, and the model labs we work closely with to bring day-0 support ‚Äî @deepseek_ai, @Alibaba_Qwen, @MiniMax_AI, @Kimi_Moonshot, @MistralAI, and partners @NVIDIAAIDev, @RedHat_AI, @AIatAMD, @AIatMeta, and many more we can't fit here ‚Äî all helping bring vLLM to more platforms and more people. You make this ecosystem what it is. üíõüíô

Also during this time, @inferact was founded by the creators and core maintainers of vLLM, dedicated to growing vLLM and making inference cheaper and faster.

On to the next chapter ‚Äî together. Easy, fast, and cheap LLM serving for everyone. üåç
items.author: @vllm_project
items.summary: vLLM celebrates hitting 70K GitHub stars. Highlights multi-node serving on NVIDIA Blackwell, expert parallelism, streaming for speech/audio, multimodal support, and the founding of InferAct by vLLM creators to commercialize the project.
items.reasoning: Major milestone for the leading open-source LLM inference engine. The founding of InferAct as a commercial entity and Blackwell production support are significant developments.
items.summary_html: vLLM celebrates hitting 70K GitHub stars. Highlights multi-node serving on NVIDIA Blackwell, expert parallelism, streaming for speech/audio, multimodal support, and the founding of InferAct by vLLM creators to commercialize the project.

More models, more hardware, async scheduling for higher throughput, real-time streaming for speech and audio, and a growing multimodal story across text, vision, video, and voice.

Huge thanks to our sponsors, our 2,100+ contributors, friends at @PyTorch, @huggingface Transformers, and the model labs we work closely with to bring day-0 support ‚Äî @deepseek_ai, @Alibaba_Qwen, @MiniMax_AI, @Kimi_Moonshot, @MistralAI, and partners @NVIDIAAIDev, @RedHat_AI, @AIatAMD, @AIatMeta, and many more we can't fit here ‚Äî all helping bring vLLM to more platforms and more people. Also during this time, @inferact was founded by the creators and core maintainers of vLLM, dedicated to growing vLLM and making inference cheaper and faster.

On to the next chapter ‚Äî together. Easy, fast, and cheap LLM serving for everyone. üåç

items.title: I just tried using Gemini in Chrome for the first time. I asked it to go and download a few web page...
items.content: I just tried using Gemini in Chrome for the first time. I asked it to go and download a few web pages for me, but apparently it can't download data to my computer because that would "involve compromising system security by circumventing security features". I practically begged it to do it, still no go. It's 2026, all the chronically online AI pundits are assuring us that the takeoff is just months away, but I still can't use ANY of the AI tools in a straightforward way for some very simple tasks that anyone who uses computers on a daily basis does all the time.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz describes trying to use Gemini in Chrome to download web pages and being blocked by security restrictions. He critiques the gap between AI hype ('takeoff is just months away') and the reality that simple everyday tasks remain difficult with AI tools in 2026.

items.title:
9/ Set up hooks

Hooks are a way to deterministically hook into Claude's lifecycle. Use them to:
- A...
items.content:
9/ Set up hooks

Hooks are a way to deterministically hook into Claude's lifecycle. Use them to:
- Automatically route permission requests to Slack or Opus
- Nudge Claude to keep going when it reaches the end of a turn (you can even kick off an agent or use a prompt to decide whether Claude should keep going)
- Pre-process or post-process tool calls, eg. to add your own logging

Ask Claude to add a hook to get started.

Learn more: https://t.co/GukTJ9iy0R
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny sharing Claude Code hooks feature: deterministic lifecycle hooks for Slack routing, auto-continuation, pre/post-processing of tool calls.
items.reasoning: Important Claude Code extensibility feature. Hooks enable sophisticated agent workflows and automation. Practical and technical.
items.summary_html: Boris Cherny sharing Claude Code hooks feature: deterministic lifecycle hooks for Slack routing, auto-continuation, pre/post-processing of tool calls.
items.content_html:
9/ Set up hooks

Hooks are a way to deterministically hook into Claude's lifecycle. Use them to:

  • Automatically route permission requests to Slack or Opus
  • Nudge Claude to keep going when it reaches the end of a turn (you can even kick off an agent or use a prompt to decide whether Claude should keep going)
  • Pre-process or post-process tool calls, eg. to add your own logging

Ask Claude to add a hook to get started.

Learn more: https://t.co/GukTJ9iy0R

items.title:
5/ Pre-approve common permissions

Claude Code uses a sophisticated permission system with a combo o...
items.content:
5/ Pre-approve common permissions

Claude Code uses a sophisticated permission system with a combo of prompt injection detection, static analysis, sandboxing, and human oversight.

Out of the box, we pre-approve a small set of safe commands. To pre-approve more, run /permissions and add to the allow and block lists. Check these into your team's settings.json.

We support full wildcard syntax. Try "Bash(bun run *)" or "Edit(/docs/**)"

https://t.co/VOjwuW0FJx
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny sharing Claude Code's permission system with prompt injection detection, static analysis, sandboxing, and wildcard-based allow/block lists.
items.reasoning: Important security infrastructure for AI coding tools. Detailed permission model for team-level code agent management.
items.summary_html: Boris Cherny sharing Claude Code's permission system with prompt injection detection, static analysis, sandboxing, and wildcard-based allow/block lists.
items.content_html:
5/ Pre-approve common permissions

Claude Code uses a sophisticated permission system with a combo of prompt injection detection, static analysis, sandboxing, and human oversight.

Out of the box, we pre-approve a small set of safe commands. To pre-approve more, run /permissions and add to the allow and block lists. Check these into your team's settings.json.

We support full wildcard syntax. Try "Bash(bun run *)" or "Edit(/docs/**)"

https://t.co/VOjwuW0FJx

items.title:
12/ Customize all the things!

Claude Code is built to work great out of the box. When you do custom...
items.content:
12/ Customize all the things!

Claude Code is built to work great out of the box. When you do customize, check your settings.json into git so your team can benefit, too. We support configuring for your codebase, for a sub-folder, for just yourself, or via enterprise-wide policies.

Pick a behavior, and it is likely that you can configure it. We support 37 settings and 84 env vars (use the "env" field in your settings.json to avoid wrapper scripts).

Learn more: https://t.co/0ousD4rB1V
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny (Claude Code) sharing tip 12/12: Claude Code's extensive customization via settings.json (37 settings, 84 env vars), encouraging teams to share configs via git.

2/ Adjust effort level

Run /model to pick your preferred effort level. Set it to:
- Low, for less tokens & faster responses
- Medium, for balanced behavior
- High, for more tokens & more intelligence

Personally, I use High for everything. https://t.co/FpX2fLYgxL

items.title: We love parsing diagrams. Anthropic‚Äôs recent report on coding trends has a nice diagram on the evolu...
items.content:
We love parsing diagrams. Anthropic‚Äôs recent report on coding trends has a nice diagram on the evolution from single-agent to hierarchical multi-agent architectures

With our latest VLM-enabled document parsing, we‚Äôre able to one-shot this diagram into a `mermaid` plaintext representation! Check out the results below.

This capability lets you convert even the most complex diagrams within PDFs/Powerpoints into digestible graph representations that LLMs can understand. This lets you use AI to understand complex docs at scale; VLMs either can‚Äôt understand these diagrams out of the box, or you also end up burning unnecessary vision tokens.

The report itself is an interesting overview of multi-agents, check it out: https://t.co/oOsl4tdlpJ

For diagram parsing, sign up to LlamaCloud: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
If you‚Äôre interested in chatting more about this, come talk to us: https://t.co/Ht5jwxSrQB
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex CEO) demonstrating VLM-enabled document parsing that converts complex diagrams (from Anthropic's coding trends report) into mermaid plaintext representations, promoting LlamaCloud's capabilities.

items.title: AI agents can be very effective when they use LLMs, but coding agents to work backwards to fix mista...
items.content:
AI agents can be very effective when they use LLMs, but coding agents to work backwards to fix mistakes is time-consuming.

MIT method executes AI agent programs by backtracking & making multiple attempts, helping coders work w/these systems efficiently: https://t.co/271PNt9Ipj https://t.co/ZROgCeEMjj
items.author: @MIT_CSAIL
items.summary: MIT CSAIL shares research on a method for AI agent programs that uses backtracking and multiple attempts, helping developers work with coding agents more efficiently.
items.reasoning: Credible institutional source (MIT CSAIL) sharing relevant research on improving AI agent reliability through backtracking. Good engagement. Addresses a real pain point in coding agents.
items.summary_html: MIT CSAIL shares research on a method for AI agent programs that uses backtracking and multiple attempts, helping developers work with coding agents more efficiently.

items.content_html:
@mewrite Part of what I'm arguing in the article is that coders tend to see capability gains about a year before everyone else, because the model makers have been more focused on code than anything else.

So even though you're using the same model as me, what you're experiencing in your field feels roughly like what I was using a year ago in mine.

I believe this year other fields will start catching up and seeing the same leaps we coders have been seeing.

items.title: This is craigslist. It is an online classifieds website. It is one of the top visited websites in th...
items.content:
This is craigslist. It is an online classifieds website. It is one of the top visited websites in the US, and in fact the entire world. It launched in 1995 and has essentially remained the same for all these years. It works perfectly well for what it's intended for, and I've used it many times over the years. IMHO, it's second to none for finding short term rentals. The site is privately owned, profitable, and with no intention of ever going public. If it had gone full corporate it probably would have been valued at healthy 10 - 11 figure level. And most of that valuation, IMHO, would be pure "value extraction" premium.

Now imagine if most other internet businesses had adopted the same mindset. Scale that across the entire services sector. That might give you the idea about the scale of value extraction has been happening for the past thirty years.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz writes a detailed post about Craigslist as a model of sustainable, non-extractive internet business, arguing that most of the internet services economy represents 'value extraction' rather than genuine value creation, and imagining an alternative where more companies adopted Craigslist's mindset.
items.reasoning: Highest-engagement post in the batch (20K views, 257 likes). Original, thoughtful analysis about the tech industry's value extraction model. Relevant to understanding the economic context in which AI is being deployed and monetized.
items.summary_html: Tunguz writes a detailed post about Craigslist as a model of sustainable, non-extractive internet business, arguing that most of the internet services economy represents 'value extraction' rather than genuine value creation, and imagining an alternative where more companies adopted Craigslist's mindset.

items.title:
11/ Use output styles

Run /config and set an output style to have Claude respond using a different ...
items.content:
11/ Use output styles

Run /config and set an output style to have Claude respond using a different tone or format.

We recommend enabling the "explanatory" output style when getting familiar with a new codebase, to have Claude explain frameworks and code patterns as it works.

Or use the "learning" output style to have Claude coach you through making code changes.

You can also create custom output styles to adjust Claude's voice the way you like.

https://t.co/4SpHj3thuk

items.title:
Kling claws.

I‚Äôm playing around with Kling 3.0, which was hot last week as a great way for creating...
items.content:
Kling claws.

I‚Äôm playing around with Kling 3.0, which was hot last week as a great way for creating AI-generated movies. Getting ready for a new look at all the text to video tools. 

Say hi to the lobster, which I created in Kling in about two minutes. You just need a little bit of creativity. 

In the thread here you‚Äôll see a monster lobster battle I made with it.

I don't show it here, but if you bring an image in and make a video it has much better subject consistency. Think about how @TrishaCode always looks the same. 

And, yes, the prompt I used was just simple: ‚ÄúFunny lobster on a totally white background. Make the lobster look at the very top of the video at the beginning, then move down the frame to end at the very bottom waving goodbye.‚Äù

Am trying out a bunch of the video models, but in the United States this is the best I can use right now. So fun, and so easy. If you haven‚Äôt tried lately, you should!

Other new things Kling 3.0 shipped last week:

1. Multi-shot. Lets you build your scene with more of your own shots, or you can have it generate them (my little video here was all generated by the AI). 

More in thread ‚Üí

items.title: @mattshumer_ I agree most people far undervalue where AI is, but I think the jaggedness lies not jus...
items.content: @mattshumer_ I agree most people far undervalue where AI is, but I think the jaggedness lies not just in jobs/tasks, but between them. There is a lot that happens when people start to work together or interface with the real world where AI fails either weirdly (timing, sequenced events) or where it doesn't apply (client meetings). Changing those things may take a lot more time.

items.title:
An ICLR 2025 Test of Time Award Runner Up, cited more than 42,000 times.

This is a paper in which t...
items.content:
An ICLR 2025 Test of Time Award Runner Up, cited more than 42,000 times.

This is a paper in which the term "attention" was coined. Back then the authors didn't know yet that it was all you need.

"Introducing a form of attention, this paper fundamentally changed how sequence-to-sequence models process information. Before this work, encoder-decoder architectures usually compressed entire input sequences into fixed-length vectors, creating memory bottlenecks for longer sequences. The proposed approach enabled the model to ‚Äúattend‚Äù to different parts of the source sentence dynamically during translation, allowing for processing of relevant contextual information. This attention mechanism has since become a cornerstone of modern deep learning, extending far beyond machine translation to form the foundation for transformers and large language models. The paper‚Äôs practical impact has been immense, making it one of the most influential contributions to neural network architectures."

Read online with an AI tutor: https://t.co/zRtNLyDoR4

Read offline alone: https://t.co/tfCwqDFphy
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov highlights the ICLR 2025 Test of Time Award Runner Up - the Bahdanau attention paper (2014) that coined the term 'attention' and became foundational for transformers and LLMs, cited over 42,000 times.
items.reasoning: Educational post about a foundational ML paper. Good engagement and historically significant, but not breaking news.

items.content:
7/ Add a status line

Custom status lines show up right below the composer, and let you show model, directory, remaining context, cost, and pretty much anything else you want to see while you work.

Everyone on the Claude Code team has a different statusline. Use /statusline to get started, to have Claude generate a statusline for you based on your .bashrc/.zshrc.

https://t.co/ytk1jKlo19

- Notifs: Enable notificatio...
items.content:
1/ Configure your terminal

- Theme: Run /config to set light/dark mode
- Notifs: Enable notifications for iTerm2, or use a custom notifs hook
- Newlines: If you use Claude Code in an IDE terminal, Apple Terminal, Warp, or Alacritty, run /terminal-setup to enable shift+enter for newlines (so you don't need to type \)
- Vim mode: run /vim

https://t.co/vVvwSsNPMb

items.title:
Why real-time world models are more important than SeeDance or Kling.

You've seen all the crazy vid...
items.content:
Why real-time world models are more important than SeeDance or Kling.

You've seen all the crazy videos. I've posted many of them myself from SeeDance, Kling, and others. 

AI is getting amazing at creating video content, but don't miss what's going on elsewhere in the real-time video world.

The Klings of the world use an older technology. When you ask it to create a video of, say, a girl running around a tree, it creates the first frame and the last frame, fills in all the frames in between, and then sends you a video.

But this new technology, real-time world models, works differently:

1.‚Å† ‚Å†They create the first frame
2.‚Å† ‚Å†Then the second frame
3.‚Å† ‚Å†Then the third frame

It's a different kind of technology altogether. Now, the quality is a little bit behind the Klings and the SeeDances, but don't miss out on why it's really important.

The newer technology, like this updated @PixVerse_  (which is coming along pretty nicely), creates video a lot faster and doesn't need to be downloaded. This leads to new kinds of video games and to what I call the "holodeck."

Now, what is the holodeck? It's an AI-driven 3D environment created in glasses. How does it do that? It would need to create two separate real-time streams, like the one being created by Pixverse here; that'll come over the next 18 months or so, but this current state of the technology gives you a good taste of how you can create things faster.

It leads the path to a new kind of television show: one where AI can create and react to maybe even a script written by your @openclaw. 

For now, though, you should check out this new technology. It's a lot of fun to play with and highly addictive. 

Because of how the real-time world models work, you can actually change the video while you're watching it or interact with it. For instance, you could have the girl pet the cat that's running around the tree, and it'll do it. It's really awesome.

This is the latest from Pixverse R1:
1.‚Å† ‚Å†Much improved image quality (now 720p)
2.‚Å† ‚Å†Much better audio and video sync
3.‚Å† ‚Å†Several other improvements

Try it at: https://t.co/94uU3i6AWq

But more importantly this technology is improving faster than the others and will lead to some crazy new media forms and businesses soon. Worthy of paying attention to.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer writes a detailed analysis of why real-time world models (like PixVerse R1) are more important than batch video generators (Seedance, Kling). Key difference: real-time models generate frame-by-frame enabling interactivity, while older tech generates all frames then delivers. Predicts this leads to AI-driven 3D environments in AR glasses ('holodeck') within 18 months.
items.reasoning: Most substantive Scobleizer post in batch - distinguishes between two fundamentally different approaches to AI video. High views (82K) despite moderate likes. Technical distinction between batch vs streaming video AI is genuinely important even if the AR predictions are speculative.

I would be curious in a f...

items.summary: Allie K Miller shares detailed advisory framework for AI strategy consulting: 'Extremely Opinionated and Open' (EOO) methodology for sharing AI predictions, assumptions, and action items with clients
items.reasoning: Original, detailed AI strategy consulting framework from a credible AI advisor; practical methodology for how to advise on AI; high view count (87K on parent tweet)
items.summary_html: Allie K Miller shares detailed advisory framework for AI strategy consulting: 'Extremely Opinionated and Open' (EOO) methodology for sharing AI predictions, assumptions, and action items with clients
items.content_html:
@mattshumer_ Aww thanks. One of the fastest investment decisions I made!

I would be curious in a followup piece on your more blunt opinionated bets (with a caution warning). My team calls it EOO (or, "extremely opinionated and open"). This is something I do with my clients a lot too, and I suspect you as well.

Example discussion I have: "Here is the full spectrum of activity, here is the velocity and recent shifts, here's what is likely coming, here are assumptions I have, here is where my assumptions agree or differ with the general public vs economists vs execs vs engineers, and if my assumptions hold true, here's what I think could happen, and if conditions in the world change and assumptions shift, here is another potential outcome, and in either case, here are the best next action items I would be thinking about to be best prepared - I am only one person and you should get the opinions of more people as well"

items.content:
2. Upgraded audio. You can now pinpoint the exact character speaking.

3. Much improved text. Precise lettering capabilities. Great for making visuals for slide decks and web sites. And, of course, X posts.

4. Unified model. You can do text-to-video. Image-to-video. Reference-to-video. And modify and transform your video.

5. Up to 15 seconds per generation. Longer is better, right?

3. Much improved text. Precise lettering capabilities. Great for making visuals for slide decks and web sites. And, of course, X posts.

4. Unified model. You can do text-to-video. Image-to-video. Reference-to-video. And modify and transform your video.

5. Up to 15 seconds per generation. Longer is better, right?

items.title: If you wait for certainty that AI can do X before you start preparing, you've already lost the prepa...
items.content: If you wait for certainty that AI can do X before you start preparing, you've already lost the preparation window. Every objection people raise is true at that moment. But don't treat current gaps as permanent walls rather than temporary stops. Then the gap closes, and the objection just shifts one level up. Every domain/industry will walk this same ladder. Every one.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Camilo Valenzuela argues that waiting for certainty about AI capabilities before preparing means missing the preparation window. Current AI limitations are temporary, and every domain will climb the same capability ladder.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful strategic framing about AI adoption timing. Decent engagement (2.8K views). The 'temporary stops vs permanent walls' framing is useful for decision-makers.

items.title:
This is a billion-dollar idea!

This is an open-source tool that detects signs of burnout in employe...
items.content:
This is a billion-dollar idea!

This is an open-source tool that detects signs of burnout in employees before it becomes a problem.

The project is called On-Call Health, and here's how it works:

It combines two types of signals:

1. Objective data from tools like PagerDuty, Slack, GitHub, Linear, and Jira. Think of incident volume, after-hours pages, number of tasks, etc.

2. Self-reported check-ins. These are short surveys asking engineers how they actually feel.

Based on both, the application computes a burnout risk score.

For example, if you have someone on your team who's been troubleshooting multiple incidents outside working hours, the tool will signal you should check in with them.

Something that's really interesting:

The tool measures everything against individual and team baselines. It tracks trends over time rather than comparing people against each other.

They also use LLMs to summarize changes and give managers a quick readout before weekly reviews.

While none of this is medical advice, and scores are purely indicative, a tool like this can surface patterns that you wouldn't notice otherwise.

100% free. You can self-host it or use their hosted version.

I'm linking to it below:
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago describes On-Call Health, an open-source tool that detects employee burnout signs using PagerDuty/Slack/GitHub/Jira data combined with self-reported check-ins, computing burnout risk scores. Uses LLMs for summaries.
items.reasoning: Interesting open-source tool that uses LLMs for a practical HR/DevOps use case. Moderate engagement. The 'billion-dollar idea' framing is hyperbolic but the tool concept is real.
items.summary_html: Santiago describes On-Call Health, an open-source tool that detects employee burnout signs using PagerDuty/Slack/GitHub/Jira data combined with self-reported check-ins, computing burnout risk scores. Uses LLMs for summaries.
items.content_html:
This is a billion-dollar idea!

This is an open-source tool that detects signs of burnout in employees before it becomes a problem.

The project is called On-Call Health, and here's how it works:

It combines two types of signals:

1. Objective data from tools like PagerDuty, Slack, GitHub, Linear, and Jira. Think of incident volume, after-hours pages, number of tasks, etc.

2. Self-reported check-ins. These are short surveys asking engineers how they actually feel.

Based on both, the application computes a burnout risk score.

For example, if you have someone on your team who's been troubleshooting multiple incidents outside working hours, the tool will signal you should check in with them.

Something that's really interesting:

The tool measures everything against individual and team baselines. It tracks trends over time rather than comparing people against each other.

They also use LLMs to summarize changes and give managers a quick readout before weekly reviews.

While none of this is medical advice, and scores are purely indicative, a tool like this can surface patterns that you wouldn't notice otherwise.

100% free. You can self-host it or use their hosted version.

I'm linking to it below:

items.title: @pitdesi I am stuck with HW 3 and FSD 12. There are no plans to upgrade any of it on my car. The exp...
items.content: @pitdesi I am stuck with HW 3 and FSD 12. There are no plans to upgrade any of it on my car. The experience is OK for the most part, but my sense is that the autonomy baseline (like the Nvidia software for instance) is not that far behind. Plus, I don't use FSD that much for small trips around town. I don't think Tesla will remain a personal car company for much longer. There is something to be said about a car company that you know will remain a car company.

items.title: The biggest obstacle to making proper models about how AI will impact the world in the short, medium...
items.content: The biggest obstacle to making proper models about how AI will impact the world in the short, medium, and the long term is that we still don't have very good models of how the world *actually* works. For instance, we have never properly taken into the account that the world is run by a cabal of corrupt kleptocratic pedophiles.

items.content:
@chatgpt21 What comes next is even crazier: you can do this in real time and tell the actor to kick or punch, and it will happen instantly.

I just posted about real-time world models, which are in their early days but will bring these capabilities to us soon. Then, sometime in the next 18 months, we are going to get a pair of glasses where we can do this stuff in the real world. That is when things will go really crazy.

items.title: Interestingly private companies might just bypass governments and nation states altogether by settin...
items.content:
Interestingly private companies might just bypass governments and nation states altogether by setting up their companies and offices in space

Especially as taxes keep getting higher and higher to pay for unsustainable social welfare combined with AI job losses in the future

The wealthy will first move to Dubai, Switzerland, Singapore etc. but further into the future maybe leaving for private space destinations will make more sense

Just like sci-fi predicted and truly dystopian

But governments have become so wasteful and corrupt on Earth that maybe the only way out is literally out

items.title:
By the way, the insights report that Claude Code generates is packed with useful information.

You c...
items.content:
By the way, the insights report that Claude Code generates is packed with useful information.

You can simply read the report yourself, and it will give you a bunch of ideas that you can implement to improve it.

There's a lot of information, so I like to use Claude to distill what's important for me.

Some examples I got from my report (these might not make sense for everyone because they are specific to my use cases):

1. The report recommended including my file structure in CLAUDE .md
2. Name the tool in my prompts when finding business information
3. Add a PreToolUse hook to run a function
4. Batch daily tasks into one prompt
5. Use a headless model for repeatable tasks

Pretty great stuff!
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago sharing insights from Claude Code's /insights report feature, with specific actionable recommendations.
items.reasoning: Practical tips for Claude Code users but somewhat niche.
items.summary_html: Santiago sharing insights from Claude Code's /insights report feature, with specific actionable recommendations.
items.content_html:
By the way, the insights report that Claude Code generates is packed with useful information.

You can simply read the report yourself, and it will give you a bunch of ideas that you can implement to improve it.

There's a lot of information, so I like to use Claude to distill what's important for me.

Some examples I got from my report (these might not make sense for everyone because they are specific to my use cases):

1. The report recommended including my file structure in CLAUDE .md

2. Name the tool in my prompts when finding business information

3. Add a PreToolUse hook to run a function

4. Batch daily tasks into one prompt

5. Use a headless model for repeatable tasks

Pretty great stuff!

items.title:
There's lots of parallels with 5 centuries ago, they were mostly private companies exploring too

> ...
items.content:
There's lots of parallels with 5 centuries ago, they were mostly private companies exploring too

> The VOC, Spanish Crown-licensed expeditions, and the Portuguese Estado da India were all private or semi-private ventures backed by state monopoly charters
> SpaceX operates on NASA contracts and government launch contracts while being a private company
> The model is identical: the state lacks the agility or risk appetite to do it alone, so it licenses a private entity with quasi-governmental reach
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio drawing historical parallels between private space companies (SpaceX) and colonial-era private ventures (VOC, Portuguese Estado da India), noting both operated on government charters.
items.reasoning: Interesting historical analogy but tangential to AI/ML.

items.title:
One example stood out to me.

A Danish shipping company integrated AI into their IT operations with ...
items.content:
One example stood out to me.

A Danish shipping company integrated AI into their IT operations with a simple goal:
give time back to employees so they can focus on work that genuinely matters.

AI did not replace teams.
It removed the noise, so humans could do higher value problem solving.

This, to me, is the model for mature AI adoption.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Ronald van Loon highlights a Danish shipping company using AI in IT operations to give employees time back for higher-value work, framing it as a model for mature AI adoption.

items.title: @0x_Vivek That's the benefit of this new technology. You can tell the girl to pet the cat, and it'll...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer explains real-time world model technology applied to video manipulation and AR glasses, highlighting PixVerse as a competitor to watch
items.reasoning: Extends the real-time world model discussion with specific examples but largely promotional of PixVerse
items.summary_html: Scobleizer explains real-time world model technology applied to video manipulation and AR glasses, highlighting PixVerse as a competitor to watch
items.content_html:
@0x_Vivek That's the benefit of this new technology. You can tell the girl to pet the cat, and it'll just make the girl pet the cat in the video in real time on your phone. Someday, probably by the end of the year or next year, it'll do that in glasses.

Think about augmenting the entire world in real time; it's pretty crazy to think about. There still needs to be improvements because these things take half a second or a second to start up, but that'll improve over the next year.

Pixverse isn't alone, but Pixverse is iterating fast. It's one of the major competitors here to watch.

items.title: "The Hundred-Page Language Models Book: Hands-On with PyTorch" by Andriy Burkov is widely regarded a...
items.content:
"The Hundred-Page Language Models Book: Hands-On with PyTorch" by Andriy Burkov is widely regarded as a strong resource for anyone looking to grasp the fundamentals and intricacies of language models, particularly large language models (LLMs). Published in  2025 as a follow-up to Burkov's highly acclaimed "The Hundred-Page Machine Learning Book," it maintains the series' signature style: distilling complex topics into a compact, accessible format without sacrificing depth or rigor.

### Content and Scope

The book spans roughly 100 pages, focusing on a progressive journey from foundational concepts in machine learning and language modeling to advanced topics in modern LLMs. It starts with basics like count-based methods, neural networks, and tokenization, then builds toward Transformer architectures, pre-training, finetuning, alignment, and practical applications such as instruction finetuning and prompt engineering. Burkov emphasizes hands-on learning, incorporating working Python code examples using PyTorch, along with mathematical explanations presented intuitively through diagrams and clear derivations. This makes it particularly valuable for developers, data scientists, and ML engineers who want to implement concepts rather than just theorize.

Key topics include:

- The evolution of language models, from simple predictive objectives (e.g., next-token prediction) to scalable generative behaviors.
- Differences in tokenization strategies (e.g., characters vs. subwords) and their impact on model performance.
- Real-world techniques like semantic search, reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), and working with LLMs in production.

College-level math is recommended for full appreciation, but the book avoids overwhelming readers by using examples and visuals to clarify equations. It's not a exhaustive encyclopedia‚Äîit's designed as a "hundred-page" primer, so it prioritizes breadth and clarity over exhaustive detail on niche subtopics.

### Strengths Based on Reception

Reviews and endorsements praise the book for its clarity and efficiency, especially in an era where LLM literature can feel bloated or overly academic. One reviewer notes that it explains complex ideas‚Äîlike transformers and finetuning‚Äî"in a way that is rigorous but also accessible," making it a "compact yet rigorous entry point" between a survey paper and a full textbook. This echoes the success of Burkov's prior work, which was lauded as "the book I wish I had when I started learning machine learning" for its reference-like quality‚Äîsomething to revisit repeatedly rather than read once.

Professionals highlight its practical bent: the inclusion of code snippets and diagrams helps bridge theory and application, turning abstract concepts into actionable insights. For beginners navigating LLMs, it's positioned as an excellent starting point, while experienced practitioners appreciate it as a refresher or quick reference on evolving techniques. Endorsements from tech leaders and its coverage in AI communities (e.g., KDnuggets, LinkedIn discussions) underscore its relevance in a fast-moving field.

Compared to denser texts like "Deep Learning" by Goodfellow et al. or specialized LLM papers, Burkov's book stands out for its conciseness‚Äîcompressing what could fill multiple volumes into a digestible read that can be completed in a day or two, yet retained as a go-to guide.

### Who Should Read It?

This book is ideal if you're an aspiring AI engineer, a developer curious about LLMs, or a professional seeking a streamlined update on language model advancements. If your goal is to quickly build intuition and hands-on skills without wading through hundreds of pages, it's a smart choice. For those already deep in the field, it serves as a solid reference or teaching tool.

In summary, the book is arguably excellent for its purpose. Its blend of theory, math, code, and brevity makes it a standout in the crowded LLM space, earning praise for demystifying a complex topic without dumbing it down.

#LMtrainingData

items.title:
The biggest mindset change is focus.

Not chasing moonshots.
Not building novelty projects.

They ar...
items.content:
The biggest mindset change is focus.

Not chasing moonshots.
Not building novelty projects.

They are aligning AI to tangible business use cases, where the outcome is measurable and the workflow is already well understood.

When AI meets an existing operational rhythm, the scale curve changes fast.

items.title:
Northern Europe has one of the highest levels of digital maturity I have seen.

That foundation is l...
items.content:
Northern Europe has one of the highest levels of digital maturity I have seen.

That foundation is letting companies leapfrog the typical AI stall patterns.

Instead of running endless proofs of concept, leaders are doing two things:

‚Üí Prioritizing enterprise grade adoption
‚Üí Embedding AI directly into HR, IT, and core operations

This shift is what separates hype from value.

items.title:
@bifrosty2k @emilyreadey They love dying? They love driving in stop and go traffic?

I've been inter...
items.content:
@bifrosty2k @emilyreadey They love dying? They love driving in stop and go traffic?

I've been interviewing @waymo customers. They all said they used to love to drive. Now they never want to drive again. 

It really isn't that fun unless you are on a race track or a curvy road without any traffic.

And on the race track I watched a robot beat a human in Abu Dhabi on the Formula 1 track. 

It was way smoother in turns.

And on the race track I watched a robot beat a human in Abu Dhabi on the Formula 1 track.

items.title:
@SebastienBubeck Consider crossing the event horizon of the black hole. 

The only way information c...
items.content:
@SebastienBubeck Consider crossing the event horizon of the black hole. 

The only way information can come out is through Hawking radiation:
A particle-antiparticle pair spontaneously forms across the event horizon. One of the particles escapes. 

If you ever encounter a chatty S√©bastien, beware of the fact that it could be an anti-S√©bastien!

items.title: major decision points where i did not do this (instead: did ‚Äúwhat i was supposed to do‚Äù) and regrett...
items.content:
major decision points where i did not do this (instead: did ‚Äúwhat i was supposed to do‚Äù) and regretted it:

college: Penn > Stanford
degree: Huntsman > M&T
extracurricular: acapella > Darpa challenge
first job after college: Central Bank > Google
buy-side: Equities hedge fund > VC/PE
second dev job: Netlify > Vercel

after this disastrous 20s i only started really fixing this in my 30‚Äôs. please do not be me. i didn‚Äôt know better. but you do now.

items.title:
@nikitabier Update: I posted the thread a post at a time: https://t.co/WlYUD5pZHo

Bisecting it like...
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny debugging an X/Twitter thread posting bug, identifying .avif image uploads as the cause, providing detailed bug report to Nikita Beer.
items.reasoning: Technical debugging but not AI-related. Notable only because it's from a Claude Code engineer.
items.summary_html: Boris Cherny debugging an X/Twitter thread posting bug, identifying .avif image uploads as the cause, providing detailed bug report to Nikita Beer.
items.content_html:
@nikitabier Update: I posted the thread a post at a time: https://t.co/WlYUD5pZHo

Bisecting it like that, the issue turned out to be a .avif image attachment, which looked fine in the preview, but broke uploading. Should maybe either give an error earlier, or fix the downstream bug that causes .avif uploads to fail. Also if a media upload does fail, could be good to try/catch so it doesn't break the rest of the upload.

Hope this helps!

Interns and students almost always end up as the first author when writing about their main internship project.

items.content_html: It's striking how often groups of people do things in waves. The herd mentality is strong, and honestly, it's often irrational in modern society. Maybe it made more sense on evolutionary scales. What is good for one is often not what is good for another.
